metadata.title: Structure-Property Relationship of Nano Enhanced Stereolithography Resin for Desktop SLA 3D Printer

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Structure-Property Relationship of Nano Enhanced Stereolithography Resin for Desktop SLA 3D Printer Zixiang Weng, Yu Zhou, Wenxiong Lin, T. Senthil, Lixin Wu PII: S1359-835X(16)30172-5 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.compositesa.2016.05.035 Reference: JCOMA 4325 To appear in: Composites: Part A Received Date: 19 February 2016 Revised Date: 25 April 2016 Accepted Date: 31 May 2016
Please cite this article as: Weng, Z., Zhou, Y., Lin, W., Senthil, T., Wu, L., Structure-Property Relationship of Nano Enhanced Stereolithography Resin for Desktop SLA 3D Printer, Composites: Part A (2016), doi: http://dx.doi.org/ 10.1016/j.compositesa.2016.05.035
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
1

sections.heading: Structure-Property Relationship of Nano Enhanced Stereolithography Resin for
sections.text:
Desktop SLA 3D Printer
Zixiang Weng a,c , Yu Zhou a , Wenxiong Lin a , T. Senthil a and Lixin Wu a,b,1
a Key Laboratory of Design and Assembly of Functional Nanostructures, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, China b Fujian Provincial Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, China c University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China
Correspondence to: L. Wu (E-mail: lxwu@fjirsm.ac.cn)
1 Correspondence to: Lixin Wu, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou 350002, China. E-mail: lxwu@fjirsm.ac.cn
2

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Organically modified nanofillers, including nano SiO2, montmorillonite and
attapulgite were loaded to stereolithography resin (SLR). The surface of nanofillers were modified using organic modifier of 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl methacrylate (γ-MPS) and (1-hexadecyl)dimethyl allyl ammonium chloride (C16-DMAAC), and were characterized by FTIR and small angle XRD analysis. The morphology of nanocomposites were observed by TEM. Viscosity and curing speed of SLR nanocomposites at increasing nanofillers loading were also studied. The mechanical properties of printed samples fabricated by a home-made stereolithography apparatus (SLA) 3D printer were tested. The influence of nanoparticles on the accuracy was measured and discussed. It was found that addition of 5% w/w of nano SiO2 increased the tensile strength and modulus by 20.6% and 65.1% respectively, and the printed accuracy was not significantly influenced. This study opens the way to the application of nanocomposites in the desktop level SLA 3D printing.
Keywords: 3D printing; nanocomposites; stereolithography resins; rapid prototyping
3

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rapid prototyping, also known as 3D printing, was developed in the late 1970s.
In recent years, on account of development in computer aided design (CAD) and material science, the application of 3D printing popularized rapidly. The accessibility of 3D printers for both industrial and general public use has grown dramatically in the past decade [1, 2]. Among various types of 3D printer, stereolithography apparatus (SLA) is used for producing models, prototypes, patterns, and production parts. During the SLA printing process, the stereolithography resin (SLR) is deposited layer by layer based on the prerequisite model, and simultaneously polymerized by an UV laser or other light sources. Typical SLRs used for SLA attached with a 355nm wavelength laser are the mixture of monomers cured by the combination of cationic mechanisms and free radical mechanisms [3, 4]. After being cured by the UV light, an interpenetrating polymer network is formed. Although 355nm SLA 3D printing can produce a wide variety of shapes, it is often expensive mainly due to the 355nm laser device and the cationic photoinitiator.
Recently, desktop level stereolithography apparatus like Formlabs SLA, digital
light projection (DLP) and continuous liquid interface production (CLIP) [5] were developed. These desktop level stereolithography apparatuses usually use 405nm (blue-ray) waveband laser device or DLP projector, and the free-radical polymerization SLR as the printing materials. When using the 405nm laser source, the beam of light focused onto the bottom surface of a tank filled with SLR. The light beam draws a layer of the object on the surface of SLR forming a cured layer due to
4
photonic polymerization. The cured layer is attached to the base or previous layer and can be peeled off from the silicon attached on the surface of the resin tank. After that, the base is raised to a certain height. Subsequently, more liquid resins refill the gap between the cured part and silicon. By repeating the above steps, the desired part can be “printed” layer by layer. The illustration of 405nm SLA 3D printer are shown in Fig. 1. These desktop level 3D printers can fabricate models faster than traditional 355nm 3D printer, and print at a reduced cost, both in terms of 3D printer and SLR.
However, problems like poor mechanical properties and poor accuracy of SLR
are common to most desktop level SLA techniques, limiting their application as functional materials.[6] Therefore, the improvement of the mechanical properties of SLRs is of interest for their applications [7, 8]. Recently, the emergence of nanocomposites has attracted great interest amongst researchers. Usually, the nano dispersion phases include nanosized metal [9], inorganic particles [10-13], fiber [14], graphene-based nanosheets [15], clay [16, 17] and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [18, 19]. Among various nanomaterials, silicon containing nanomaterials have been extensively investigated due to their interesting mechanical properties and potential technological applications as reinforcing filler in a broad range of polymers. Nanocomposites consisting of a polymer and silicon containing nanomaterials frequently exhibit remarkably enhanced properties including mechanical properties [20, 21], heat resistance [22], low gas permeability [23] and flame retardancy [24]. These enhanced properties in nanocomposites are mainly due to stronger interfacial interaction between the polymer matrix and the surface of the silicon containing
5
nanomaterials. Because of its special surface chemistry, silicon containing nanomaterials can be easily functionalized, and can be readily modified and dispersed in polymer to form nanocomposites.
Although polymer nanocomposites have been well studied, the application of
nanomaterials into SLR is less reported. Moreover, the relationship of morphology and structure of nanomaterials on the rheological properties and mechanical properties of SLR is rarely studied. In this paper, the effect of nanomaterials with different morphologies on the properties of SLR was investigated. Three types of silicon containing nanomaterials were used: silica (SiO2), attapulgite (ATP), and organic montmorillonite (OMMT), corresponding to sphere (0D), rod like (1D) and sheets (2D) respectively. Unlike traditional moulding or casting processes, the primary concern of UV curable resins used in SLA technique are viscosity and refractive index of the resin. Poor flowability will cause difficulties in refilling SLR, and improper refractive index will absorb or scatter UV light, leading to processing defects, incomplete curing, reduction in mechanical properties and accuracy. Therefore, a systematic study is explored on how the introduction of different morphology of nanofillers change the rheology, UV cure kinetic and mechanical properties of nanocomposites.
6

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text:
The SLR compound used here was a mixture of an aliphatic urethane acrylate
oligomer (CN9010, Sartomer Americas, USA), an aliphatic polyester based urethane diacrylate oligomer (CN991, Sartomer Americas, USA), tetraethylene glycol dimethacrylate (SR209, Sartomer Americas, USA), hydroxyethyl methacrylate (HEMA, Aladdin Industrial Inc., China) and hydroxypropyl methacrylate (HPMA, Aladdin Industrial Inc., China). The photo initiator (PI) was 2,4,6-trimethyl benzoyl diphenyl phosphine oxide (TPO, Aladdin Industrial Inc., China). Pristine silica with an average particle diameter of 30nm waspurchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc., China. Attapulgite (TW-01) was purchased from Jiangsu Jiuchuan Nano-material Technology Co. Ltd., China. Pristine montmorillonite (PGW) was provided by Nanocor, USA. 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl methacrylate (γ-MPS), was provided by Aladdin Industrial Inc., China. (1-hexadecyl) dimethyl allyl ammonium chloride (C16-DMAAC) was provided by Zhangjiagang Halberdo Chemical Co., Ltd.,. 2.2 Organic modification of nanomaterials
The synthetic routes of organic modified nanoparticles were presented in Fig. 2.
Due to the SLR is a free-radical polymerization monomer mixture, the object of organic modification is to introduce reactive alkene onto the surface of SiO2 and ATP, or inside the galleries of montmorillonite.

sections.heading: Modification of SiO2
sections.text:
For the modification of SiO2, γ-MPS was used. According to the procedure
7
reported by Abbound [25], grafting was carried out under an argon atmosphere. 10g pristine silica was dispersed in 200mL of toluene and then γ-MPS was added dropwise to the mixture. The reaction was carried out for 15h equipped with a reflux unit. By pressure filtration, organic modified SiO2 was separated from the medium, washed repeatedly with distilled water and freeze dried, thus the fine particles of organic modified SiO2 was obtained. Modification of attapulgite
Due to the similarity of structure to SiO2, γ-MPS was also used to modify the
surface of ATP. According to Wang’s report [26], 10g of pristine attapulgite was acidize by 1mol/L HCl and added to a mixture of isopropanol and water (9:1), and 3g γ-MPS was added. By sonication and filtration, a filter cake was obtained and dried by freeze drier and finally organic modified ATP was obtained.

sections.heading: Modification of montmorillonite
sections.text:
According to Pinnavaia’s report [27], 10g pristine montmorillonite was dispersed
into 500mL of distilled water at 60°C and the suspension was obtained. A stoichiometric quantity of C16-DMAAC was added to the suspension and stirred for 5h. Then the suspension was cooled down to room temperature and poured into a pressure filtration device. Organic modified montmorillonite (OMMT) is separated by pressure filtration and washed several times with distilled water until no chloridion was detected by 0.1M AgCl solution, the filter cake was obtained. In order to prevent agglomeration, the filter cake was dried by a freeze drier and fine powder of OMMT was obtained.
8

sections.heading: 2.3 Preparation of nanocomposites
sections.text:
To prepare the nanocomposite, measured amount of organic modified
nanoparticles were added into SLR by continuous stirring. An ultrasonic cell disintegrator was used for the dispersion nanoparticles. Subsequently, photoinitiator was added into the mixture and stirred for 5min. The fine bubbles were removed by a planetary vacuum gravity mixer and all the SLR nanocomposites mixtures were stored in a dark room.

sections.heading: 2.4 Fabrication of three-dimensional parts by stereolithography apparatus
sections.text:
When the intensity of the UV light keeps constant, the UV-curable resin beyond
the curing depth (CD) cannot be cured completely because the intensity of light decreases with the increase of resin depth due to scattering/absorption, thus each printed layer should have a layer thickness less than or equal to the curing depth. In this paper, test samples were printed by a homemade 405nm SLA apparatus according to the ASTM standard D638. The general view of the homemade 405nm SLA apparatus was shown in Fig. 3. The irradiation of laser was set to 155mW/cm 2 . The scan speed of the galvanometer was set to 2000mm/s according to our previous optimizing study. After printing, the samples were washed by isopropanol several times. All the samples were tested directly without any post curing.

sections.heading: Rheological studies
sections.text:
A Rheometer (Discovery Hybrid Rheometer-2, DHR-2, TA, USA) with parallel
plate geometry was used for rheological studies. The diameter of geometry was 40
9
mm, and relative data were collected by non-iteration method. The range of steady state shear rate was from 20 to 1000s -1 . The temperature was set to 25°C. The gap between two geometries is 1mm. An UV LED accessory of DHR-2 was used to investigate the curing process of SLR nanocomposites. The upper geometry was made of aluminum and its diameter was 20mm and the lower geometry was made of transparent PMMA with a diameter of 20mm too. The duration of the experiment was 60s, the UV LED was turned on at the 20 th second and the irradiation power was 155mW/cm 2 .

sections.heading: FTIR and low angle XRD
sections.text:
The chemical structure of organically modified and pristine nanoparticles was
analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Thermo Nicolet 5700, USA) in the range of 500-4000cm -1 . The microstructure OMMT was determined by low angle XRD (X’Pert Pro MPD, Philips, Netherlands) using a Cu-Kα radiation (l=1.78901 Å).

sections.heading: Transmission electron microscopy
sections.text:
A transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010, Japan) was
employed to observe the morphologies of SLR nanocomposites. The acceleration voltage was 200kV. All samples were made by ultrathin sectioning.

sections.heading: Mechanical properties
sections.text:
The tensile strength and elastic modulus were obtained from a universal material
test machine (AGX-100 plus, Shimadzu, Japan). The elastic modulus is obtained from a non-contact extensometer at room temperature. The test speed was 2mm/min.
10

sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization of organomodified nanoparticles
sections.text:
In this study, the modification of ATP and SiO2 were confirmed by FTIR and that
of organic montmorillonite was confirmed by low angle XRD. Fig. 4 shows the FTIR spectra of γ-MPS, SiO2, γ-MPS modified SiO2, ATP and γ-MPS modified ATP. In the spectra, the peaks at 2947cm -1 and 2841cm -1 belong to C-H stretching and the strong peak at 1719cm -1 corresponds to ester group [25]. These two characteristic peaks can be observed in γ-MPS and its modified nanoparticles, however they cannot be observed in pristine SiO2 and ATP. It can be confirmed that γ-MPS had been grafted onto the surface of the nanoparticles successfully.
Low angle XRD was carried out to examine the delamination of OMMT. The
XRD pattern (Fig. 5) of the pristine montmorillonite showed a primary silicate (001) reflection at 2θ=8.08°. According to Bragg equation, the main silicate reflection in pristine montmorillonite indicates an interlayer spacing of 1.27nm. By ion exchange with C16-DMAAC, OMMT shows a primary silicate (001) reflection at 2θ=4.49°, indicating an interlayer spacing of 2.28nm. Such increase of interlayer spacing confirms that the organic modifier had been exchanged into the intergallery of the montmorillonite successfully.

sections.heading: 3.2 Transmission electron microscopy
sections.text:
The morphology and the dispersion of the nanoparticles in the SLR
nanocomposites were studied by TEM. Fig. 6 shows the morphology of three representative SLR nanocomposites with different nanofillers (all nanofiller loading
11
were 5% w/w). From Fig. 6, it can be seen that the organic modified SiO2 particles were well dispersed in polymer matrix without obvious aggregation. The average diameter of SiO2 is about 30nm. However, in the case of OMMT, the intergallery space is larger than pristine montmorillonite and no exfoliation was observed, as similar to the previous reports [28, 29]. It was reported [30-32] that the competition between the intergallery polymerization and the extragallery polymerization dominates the dispersion of OMMT layers. When the intergallery polymerization is faster than the extragallery polymerization, the gaps between layers are expanded, resulting in exfoliated structure or large d-spacing. On the opposite, when the intergallery polymerization is slower than the extragallery polymerization, a smaller d-spacing structure is normally formed. During SLA 3D printing process, the layers of OMMT block the laser beam, resulting in slower intergallery polymerization than the extragallery polymerization. This can explain why only intercalated structure forms were observed. In the TEM images of ATP, the structure of ATP and some aggregation can be observed. The surface of ATP is covered with positively charged magnesium atoms. The weak hydrogen bonds between positively charged magnesium atoms at the surface and negatively charged hydroxyl groups in the ATP itself can lead to the aggregation of ATP. This hydrogen bonds cannot be broken by sonication or by surface organic modification. Therefore, under the same processing condition, the SiO2 possess the best dispersion in the SLR matrix as evident in the TEM images. 3.3 Rheological characterization
Due to the way of fabricating objects by 3D printing, the viscosity of the uncured
12
SLR must be as low as possible to allow a good recoat of the liquid monomer on the polymerized underlayer [33, 34]. In order to study the effect of nanoparticles with different morphologies in SLR matrix, the viscosity of the samples were tested. Fig. 7 shows the viscosity of different SLR nanocomposites. For SiO2/SLR nanocomposites up to 5% w/w SiO2 loading, it can be observed that no significant change in viscosity with increase shear rate as compared to the neat SLR. When SiO2 loading increased to 10% w/w, the SLR nanocomposites exhibit a faint sheared dilution behavior. When the shear rate increased to 500s -1
, the viscosity stopped decreasing. Unlike SiO2/SLR
nanocomposites, the ATP/SLR and OMMT/SLR exhibit a shear thinning behavior, which is similar to previous reports [29, 35]. At high shear rate region, the ATP/SLR and OMMT/SLR even exhibit a lower viscosity than SiO2/SLR.
Usually, the rheological behavior depicts the dynamic behavior of structural units
that can change orientation during deformation and aggregation/deaggregation of the fillers. In the case of SiO2/SLR nanocomposite, due to the spherical shape of SiO2 nanoparticles, at low shear rate, the higher viscosity is mainly due to the contact between the rigid SiO2 and immobilized SLR. At high shear rate, the SiO2 nanoparticles deaggregate and the immobilized SLR chains can be released, as a result, in a macroscopic perspective, the viscosity decreases. The schematic illustration can be seen in Fig. 8. Unlike SiO2/SLR nanocomposites, ATP/SLR and OMMT/SLR nanocomposites exhibit more evident shear thinning behavior. At low shear rate zone, uncured ATP/SLR and OMMT/SLR nanocomposites exhibit higher viscosity than SiO2/SLR nanocomposites. However at high shear rate zone, it is
13
interesting to see that they possess a lower viscosity than SiO2/SLR nanocomposites and it is caused by the spatial structure of nanofiller.
In low shear rate zone, the ATP and OMMT immobilized the SLR molecular
chain more effectively compared to SiO2 due to larger surface area and entanglement. With the increase of shear rate, ATP and OMMT nano particles detach and these nanoparticles can be orientated along the direction of shear force. This orientation of nanoparticles along the direction of shear force offer a lower resistance to the shear deformation and thereby a lower viscosity can be observed at this region. According to our previous test results, for nanofiller loading above 5% w/w, viscosity of SLR nanocomposites were too high to be used in present SLA 3D printer. If the viscosity is too high, the SLR cannot fill the gap between the last layer of model and silicon within the stipulated time, leading to a fabrication failure while the base is raised. Therefore, it can be concluded that 5% w/w of any nanofiller loading to SLR has the maximum viscosity to match with the requirements of the present stereolithography apparatus.
An UV LED accessory of DHR-2 was used to investigate the curing behavior of
SLR nanocomposites. The principle of the accessory is illustrated in Fig. 9. By fast sampling, the change in storage modulus and loss modulus of the sample during the curing processes can be recorded. Fig. 10 shows the curing behavior of SLR nanocomposite loaded with 10% w/w of SiO2, ATP and OMMT, respectively.
For UV-initiated polymerization and cross-linking, nanoparticles influence the
gel time in two opposite factors: 1) the reinforcing effect of nanoparticles may
14
promote the crosslink and increase the modulus of SLR, therefore shorten the gel time; 2) the nanoparticles may block the light, inhibiting the photonic polymerization, and therefore prolong the gel time. Fig. 10 shows that the addition of SiO2 shorten the gel time a little bit, because it is dominated by the reinforcing effect. However the rodlike structure of APT and layered structure of MMT have larger surface area, which may block the light. Therefore addition of ATP and MMT prolong the gel time which is dominated by the inhibiting polymerizaion effect as shown in Fig. 11.

sections.heading: 3.4 Mechanical properties
sections.text:
The tensile strength of different SLR nanocomposites and the corresponding
elastic modulus are shown in Fig. 12. The corresponding data are listed in Table 1. It is important to mention that, unlike thermosetting epoxy resin and traditional UV curable resin made by conventional methods, the “printed” samples exhibit different fracture behavior. The yield strain behavior of neat SLR and SLR nanocomposites are entirely different and such unusual yield strain behavior can be interpreted as incomplete curing of the nanocomposites. The uncured polymer chain would unwrap under applied stress leading to a longer elongation.
When nanoparticles were introduced, the elastic modulus of all resins has been
improved. The reduced elongation at break of the nanocomposites suggests that nanofiller can suppress the macromolecular mobility to a large extent [36]. However, only by introducing SiO2, the tensile strength is improved slightly [37]. In the case of OMMT/SLR nanocomposites the tensile strength is irrespective of the clay loading. For ATP/SLR nanocomposites, the tensile strength was reduced with the increase of
15
filler loading. Wang [31] and Sheng [26] reported that the tensile strength can be improved significantly by introducing OMMT and ATP, however, in SLR system, such an improvement was not observed. The interpretation from cure kinetics can also be applied here: since the UV light is absorbed/scattered by OMMT and ATP, the cross linking density is decreased. At the macroscopic level, such lower cross linking density leads to worse mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 3.5 Fabrication of three-dimensional objects by SLA 3D printer
sections.text:
Unlike traditional UV curable resin coating, printing accuracy is also a concern in
SLA techniques. In order to qualify the printing accuracy of SLA nanocomposites, a stereo cross model was printed. As shown in Fig. 13, the length of the model was 50mm. The nanopartilces of all three nanocomposites loading were 3% w/w. The proper power of laser and scanning speed of galvanometer were set according to our previous study. After printing, the supports of the samples were removed and the models were washed by isopropanol.
From Fig. 13, it can be observed that neat SLR and its nanocomposites can be
printed by our SLA 3D printer. However, the accuracy was affected by the nanofiller loaded to SLR mixture. Under the same printing conditions (fixed power and fixed scan speed), neat SLR and SiO2/SLR nanocomposites exhibit good accuracy and the exact length of the model was 50.03mm and 50.07mm respectively. Compared with CAD file, the error for SLR was 0.06% and for SiO2/SLR nanocomposites was 0.14% respectively.
However, when OMMT and ATP were added into SLR, the accuracy become
16
worse. For OMMT/SLR nanocomposites, the exact length of the model was 50.96mm. For ATP/SLR nanocomposites, the exact length of the model was 51.12mm. This is due to that the UV light cannot penetrate SLR completely since the UV wave was absorbed/scattered by OMMT and ATP. The scattered UV light would initiate polymerization of the SLR around the laser point, resulting in a longer length of the model. When the SLR nanocomposite is used in SLA 3D printer, more factors should be considered including organic modification, refractive index, depth of curing, curing shrinkage etc. It can be concluded that SiO2/SLR nanocomposite can be considered to be the best as compared with ATP/SLR and OMMT/SLR nanocomposite based on the print accuracy and mechanical properties due to well dispersed SiO2 and its sphere structure.
17

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Nano SiO2, ATP and OMMT were added into SLR to form nanocomposites. The
morphology of nanoparticles in SLR matrix, rheology of SLR, curing kinetic and mechanical properties were studied. Rheology analysis showed that when nanofiller loading increased to 10% w/w, the viscosity of SLR increased rapidly and are not suitable for current SLA 3D printer. It was found that the addition of nano SiO2 increased the curing speed of SLR, while the addition of OMMT and ATP decreased the curing speed. Addition of all nanofillers increased the elastic modulus of SLR. However, only organic modified nano SiO2 can increased tensile strength significantly. The accuracy measurement showed that only addition of nano SiO2 had less effect on the dimension of printed samples. It is concluded that nano SiO2 is the best reinforcement for SLR among three kinds of studied nanoparticles.
18

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text:
This research was financially supported by the National Natural Science
Foundation of China (Grant No.: U1205114), the Science Foundation of Fujian province (Grant No.: 2014J01217 and 2015H0047), and the "Strategic Priority Research Program" of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Grant No.: XDA09020301).
19
